page.title: 07WESTBURY WHITE HORSE
page.content: Amongst the most familiar landmarks in Wiltshire are the White Horses cut into the chalk of the downland slopes. Of these, the Westbury White Horse, the most southerly example, is perhaps the best known and certainly the best sited, about two miles from Westbury on Bratton Down immediately below the ramparts of the Iron Age hillfort known as Bratton Castle. Its position commands a magnificient prospect of Pewsey Vale. The Westbury horse is the oldest of the Wiltshire horses and dates from 1779 but it is also the second of its line, having been preceded on the same site by an older horse of uncertain age and origin. Local tradition holds that it was cut to commemorate one of King Alfred's victories over the Danes in A.D.878, but this cannot be proved.
